articles.headline: Downgrade of Debt Ratings Underscores Europe’s Woes
articles.snippet: Combined with a snag in talks between Greece and its creditors, the ratings agency Standard & Poor’s action served as a reminder that Europe has found no solution to its debt turmoil.
articles.abstract: Combined with a snag in talks between Greece and its creditors, the ratings agency Standard & Poor’s action served as a reminder that Europe has found no solution to its debt turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Standard & Poor’s downgraded the credit ratings of France, Italy and seven other European countries on Friday, a move that may have more symbolic than fundamental financial impact but served as a reminder that Europe’s economic woes were far from over.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Rachel Donadio

articles.headline: Apple Lists Its Suppliers for 1st Time
articles.snippet: The move accompanied a report detailing troubling practices inside many of the facilities.
articles.abstract: The move accompanied a report detailing troubling practices inside many of the facilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple released a list of its major suppliers for the first time on Friday, bringing the company up to par with other big American corporations, including Hewlett-Packard, Intel and Nike, which have released similar lists.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Charles Duhigg

articles.headline: Financial Advice for Those With Small Nest Eggs
articles.snippet: Although the class snobbery among brokerage firms is fading, people of modest means still find it hard to receive reasonably priced financial advice.
articles.abstract: Although the class snobbery among brokerage firms is fading, people of modest means still find it hard to receive reasonably priced financial advice.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Merrill Lynch recently discouraged its thundering herd of brokers from taking on new clients with under $250,000 in assets available for investing, it wasn’t a big surprise.

articles.headline: Owner as Regulator, Like Oil and Water
articles.snippet: The government’s controlling stake in General Motors proves that ownership and regulation are inherently incompatible.
articles.abstract: The government’s controlling stake in General Motors proves that ownership and regulation are inherently incompatible.
articles.lead_paragraph: Let’s say you’re the biggest owner of a global auto company. You take the company’s flagship new vehicle, twist it, crash it, poke it and leave it outside in the elements for weeks until its battery catches fire. Then you generate a storm of publicity and watch the share price and the value of your ownership stake decline.

articles.headline: In France, the Pain of Rating Downgrade Is Especially Acute
articles.snippet: Keeping its AAA credit rating had long been a badge of honor for the country and a political point of pride for President Nicolas Sarkozy.
articles.abstract: Keeping its AAA credit rating had long been a badge of honor for the country and a political point of pride for President Nicolas Sarkozy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Among the European countries that Standard & Poor’s declared less creditworthy on Friday, France stands out among the tarnished.

articles.headline: Town, Cast as Romney’s Victim, Says, ‘Huh?’
articles.snippet: The closing of a factory in Gaffney, S.C., by Bain Capital, Mitt Romney’s firm, is cited in his rivals’ attacks, but few in town remember the closing, or care.
articles.abstract: The closing of a factory in Gaffney, S.C., by Bain Capital, Mitt Romney’s firm, is cited in his rivals’ attacks, but few in town remember the closing, or care.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAFFNEY, S.C. — This small Southern town that once boomed with peaches and cotton mills has found itself the unexpected star of the latest bruising fight in the race for the Republican presidential nomination.

articles.headline: The Image Officer With a Lot to Fix
articles.snippet: Though not technically a banker, Anne M. Finucane of Bank of America is one of the most powerful figures in its industry. And now it’s up to her to help repair the bank’s reputation.
articles.abstract: Though not technically a banker, Anne M. Finucane of Bank of America is one of the most powerful figures in its industry. And now it’s up to her to help repair the bank’s reputation.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT’S show time for Anne M. Finucane.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: Digitizing Health Records, Before It Was Cool
articles.snippet: In the growing business of electronic medical records, Epic Systems is far from a newcomer: it started more than 30 years ago, and now helps keep track of 40 million patients.
articles.abstract: In the growing business of electronic medical records, Epic Systems is far from a newcomer: it started more than 30 years ago, and now helps keep track of 40 million patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: VERONA, Wis.

articles.headline: Secrets of a Sales Machine
articles.snippet: Citigroup didn’t succeed in a challenge of an arbitration panel’s decision in favor of two investors. But in the process, the bank laid bare some of its inner workings.
articles.abstract: Citigroup didn’t succeed in a challenge of an arbitration panel’s decision in favor of two investors. But in the process, the bank laid bare some of its inner workings.
articles.lead_paragraph: BACK in 1940, a popular book about Wall Street asked, “Where are the customers’ yachts?” Investment firms, it lamented, always seemed to win, even when their customers lost.

articles.headline: Evangelicals, Seeking Unity, Back Santorum for Nomination
articles.snippet: Christian leaders voted to support the presidential candidacy of Rick Santorum in hopes of undercutting Mitt Romney’s dominance of the Republican field.
articles.abstract: Christian leaders voted to support the presidential candidacy of Rick Santorum in hopes of undercutting Mitt Romney’s dominance of the Republican field.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRENHAM, Tex. — Evangelical leaders pursued a last-ditch effort on Saturday to exert influence in the Republican presidential primary race, voting to support the candidacy of Rick Santorum in hopes of undercutting Mitt Romney’s march to the nomination.
articles.byline: By Erik Eckholm and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Romney Offers Praise for a Donor’s Business
articles.snippet: With for-profit colleges under siege in Washington over accusations that they defraud students, Mitt Romney’s endorsement of them puts him in the middle of a political debate.
articles.abstract: With for-profit colleges under siege in Washington over accusations that they defraud students, Mitt Romney’s endorsement of them puts him in the middle of a political debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a town-hall-style meeting in New Hampshire last month, listeners pressed Mitt Romney on the soaring cost of higher education. His solution: students should consider for-profit colleges like the little-known Full Sail University in Florida.

articles.headline: Among the Wealthiest 1 Percent, Many Variations
articles.snippet: While the 1 percent has become a catch-all to describe the very wealthy, the members of this group are diverse, especially in where they live, what they believe politically and just how rich they are.
articles.abstract: While the 1 percent has become a catch-all to describe the very wealthy, the members of this group are diverse, especially in where they live, what they believe politically and just how rich they are.
articles.lead_paragraph: KINGS POINT, N.Y. — Adam Katz is happy to talk to reporters when he is promoting his business, a charter flight company based on Long Island called Talon Air.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: Boehner Faces a Restive G.O.P. and New White House Attacks
articles.snippet: In the new session, Speaker John A. Boehner’s challenge is not only to corral House Republicans but also to preserve his party’s majority and fend off attacks from President Obama.
articles.abstract: In the new session, Speaker John A. Boehner’s challenge is not only to corral House Republicans but also to preserve his party’s majority and fend off attacks from President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Speaker John A. Boehner and House Republicans, returning to the Capitol this week could have the awkward feeling of a couple waking up after a night of fighting.

articles.headline: Israelis Facing a Seismic Rift Over Role of Women
articles.snippet: A series of episodes involving the ultra-Orthodox community, including segregation of women and protests comparing officials to Nazis, has set off a debate about its position.
articles.abstract: A series of episodes involving the ultra-Orthodox community, including segregation of women and protests comparing officials to Nazis, has set off a debate about its position.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In the three months since the Israeli Health Ministry awarded a prize to a pediatrics professor for her book on hereditary diseases common to Jews, her experience at the awards ceremony has become a rallying cry.
articles.byline: By Ethan Bronner and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Fear of Civil War Mounts in Syria as Crisis Deepens
articles.snippet: The failure of an Arab League mission and a government as defiant as its opposition is in disarray have thrust Syria into what increasingly looks like a protracted and chaotic conflict.
articles.abstract: The failure of an Arab League mission and a government as defiant as its opposition is in disarray have thrust Syria into what increasingly looks like a protracted and chaotic conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The failure of an Arab League mission to stanch violence in Syria, an international community with little leverage and a government as defiant as its opposition is in disarray have left Syria descending into a protracted, chaotic and perhaps unnegotiable conflict.

articles.headline: Inefficient Economies Seen as Drag on Europe
articles.snippet: In confronting the debt crisis, European leaders must not lose sight of the need to rebuild their economies by investing in technology or making labor markets more flexible, analysts say.
articles.abstract: In confronting the debt crisis, European leaders must not lose sight of the need to rebuild their economies by investing in technology or making labor markets more flexible, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — As France and other European nations grapple with the downgrade of their sovereign debt by Standard & Poor’s on Friday, a longer-term test looms over whether those nations will now turn toward improving Europe’s economic competitiveness.

articles.headline: Online Shoppers Are Rooting for the Little Guy
articles.snippet: As online giants act more like big-box stores, smaller sites are positioning themselves as mom-and-pop alternatives.
articles.abstract: As online giants act more like big-box stores, smaller sites are positioning themselves as mom-and-pop alternatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: Harold Pollack used to spend $1,000 a year on Amazon, but this fall started buying from small online retailers instead. The prices are higher, but Dr. Pollack says he now has a clear conscience.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: As Reforms Flag in Greece, Europe Aims to Limit Damage
articles.snippet: European officials say the task of negotiations with lenders is less to help Greece through its troubles than to avoid an uncontrolled default that could threaten the global financial system.
articles.abstract: European officials say the task of negotiations with lenders is less to help Greece through its troubles than to avoid an uncontrolled default that could threaten the global financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — As Greece and its lenders prepare for another week of tense negotiations, European officials now say that the task is less to help the country through its troubles than to avoid the sort of uncontrolled default that many experts fear could threaten the global financial system.
articles.byline: By Rachel Donadio and Niki Kitsantonis

articles.headline: Hollywood Techniques at Play in Politics
articles.snippet: A documentary-style film relentlessly attacking Mitt Romney has unnerved some in Hollywood with its attention to form.
articles.abstract: A documentary-style film relentlessly attacking Mitt Romney has unnerved some in Hollywood with its attention to form.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hollywood came early to the 2012 presidential race in the unlikely form of “When Mitt Romney Came to Town,” the 28-minute documentary-style attack film that opens with the word “capitalism” and comes to an end with chants of “Wall Street greed.”

articles.headline: Enquirer Designs an App for Gossip
articles.snippet: The National Enquirer will introduce an iPad app next month that will have separate content from the print publication and video aimed at younger readers.
articles.abstract: The National Enquirer will introduce an iPad app next month that will have separate content from the print publication and video aimed at younger readers.
articles.lead_paragraph: American Media Inc. is hoping that enquiring minds will embrace a digital version of its 70-year-old supermarket tabloid, The National Enquirer.

articles.headline: Bills to Stop Web Piracy Invite a Protracted Battle
articles.snippet: The Obama administration’s statement of opposition to antipiracy legislation let the technology industry claim a victory, but few in Silicon Valley or Hollywood consider the battle over.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration’s statement of opposition to antipiracy legislation let the technology industry claim a victory, but few in Silicon Valley or Hollywood consider the battle over.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Obama administration announced on Saturday its opposition to major elements of two Congressional bills intended to curtail copyright violations on the Internet, the technology industry, which has been loudly fighting the proposed legislation, could declare victory.
articles.byline: By Jenna Wortham and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: Flexing Muscle, Baghdad Detains U.S. Contractors
articles.snippet: The crackdown comes amid other moves by the government to take over functions once performed by the United States military and to claim areas of the country it had controlled.
articles.abstract: The crackdown comes amid other moves by the government to take over functions once performed by the United States military and to claim areas of the country it had controlled.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraqi authorities have detained a few hundred foreign contractors in recent weeks, industry officials say, including many Americans who work for the United States Embassy, in one of the first major signs of the Iraqi government’s asserting its sovereignty after the American troop withdrawal last month.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Donors Gave as Santorum Won Earmarks
articles.snippet: An examination of some of the earmarks Rick Santorum got as a senator from Pennsylvania suggests that they paid off in the form of campaign contributions.
articles.abstract: An examination of some of the earmarks Rick Santorum got as a senator from Pennsylvania suggests that they paid off in the form of campaign contributions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The announcements flowed out of Rick Santorum’s Senate office: a $3.5 million federal grant to Piasecki Aircraft to help it test a new helicopter propeller technology; another $3.5 million to JLG Industries to bolster its bid to build all-terrain forklifts for the military; $1.4 million to Medico Industries to upgrade equipment for its munitions work.
articles.byline: By Michael Luo and Mike McIntire

articles.headline: A Changed Way of War in Afghanistan’s Skies
articles.snippet: The use of air power has changed markedly during the long Afghan conflict, reflecting the political costs and sensitivities of civilian casualties and the increasing use of aerial drones.
articles.abstract: The use of air power has changed markedly during the long Afghan conflict, reflecting the political costs and sensitivities of civilian casualties and the increasing use of aerial drones.
articles.lead_paragraph: INSIDE STRIKE FIGHTER VENGEANCE 13, over Kandahar Province, Afghanistan — Cmdr. Layne McDowell glanced over his left shoulder, through the canopy of a Navy F/A-18, to an Afghan canyon 9,000 feet below. An American infantry company was down there.

articles.headline: Oversight of Cruise Lines at Issue After Disaster
articles.snippet: Questions about a captain’s maneuvering of the Costa Concordia cruise ship off the coast of Italy are raising larger issues about how the cruise industry is regulated.
articles.abstract: Questions about a captain’s maneuvering of the Costa Concordia cruise ship off the coast of Italy are raising larger issues about how the cruise industry is regulated.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — As the world was transfixed by the Titanic-like imagery of the partly submerged Costa Concordia and the frantic efforts to save the fuel-laden vessel in rough seas off the Tuscany coast, questions swirled on Monday about the enormous cruise line industry, which operates without much regulation.
